comments.commentBody: Well put, David.  Displaying contempt and disgust for an indigenous people trying to support themselves is easy for the international urban.  Now, how about some indignation and outrage for the bureaucracies and 'elected' officials who destroyed their traditional economy, hmm?
Keynes didn't exactly say that markets wouldn't clear, as I recall. He said that the labor market wouldn't necessarily clear at wages high enough to live on.

In the model Keynes developed, if aggregate demand is inadequate the labor market does not clear. A clearing labor market is a special case in this model that holds only if aggregate demand is strong enough. The failure of the labor market to clear feeds back into the product market through the consumption function and thereby reduces aggregate demand.

Regular economics is a special theory of the economy which only holds if prices are perfectly flexible and therefore transactions do not take place when markets do not clear, so that markets, after transactions having taken place, are left with excess demand (shortages) or excess supply (like unemployment.)

This special theory is inadequate when economies are in recessions and depressions (or inflationary booms). What is needed is a general theory of the economy that holds whether markets do or do not clear, and in which the market-clearing case is a special case of the more general theory. This is what Keynes did in the General Theory and what Keynesian economics, if done properly, does.
Illiterate but very smart

This reference, while long, will explain the context of this comment. You marry a family in India and mother in laws are truly the focus of the family.

http://madh-mama.blogspot.com/2013/08/the-psychology-of-indian-mother-in...

The link shows no difference in death rates of term deliveries but labor was 30 minutes longer and women were much less likely to receive any anesthesia when attended by a mid-wife.  So yes, you might save money if you are willing to have a longer labor but if something goes wrong, you better hope an obstetrician is around to save the life of the mother.

In the western world, midwife-led births have far lower rates of complications and are far safer, in normal or low risk births, compared to obstetrician-led births:

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23963739

For those who don't understand research - the above-linked study is considered the highest level of scientific evidence that exists in medicine - a Cochrane Review. In this case, one that looked at the 13 randomized, controlled trials, involving over 16,000 births.

Yet the obstetricians have been lobbying US Congress to limit insurance reimbursement for midwives.

Just one of multitudes of similar situations in medicine - inferior conventional medicine uses media such as NYT to put forth propoganda, uses Congress and state legislatures to write laws giving it advantage in the marketplace, etc - all to the detriment of the unknowing public....

I don't know which language he should choose but he needs to learn how to read and is crying out for the opportunity. I can't imagine that he has no ability to read or that he hasn't tried before but if it hasn't happened yet, why wait longer?

Good news to anyone flying into or out of Bombay. The expansion is long-overdue but in the medium-long term, the problem will be, as with all major infrastructure in India, that of maintenance. Without constant refurbishment and repair, an airport handling millions of passengers a year will quickly become shabby; facilities will break down and large portions of the terminals will become unusable. And the temptation for political interference by notoriously corrupt politicians is immense. Unfortunately, this is a story that is repeated all over India. Airports such as Changi, Dubai, and Hong Kong cost a fortune to run and maintain, but in all three locations there are governments/corporations that are willing to spend that money because they know that the reputation and efficiency of their stellar airports depend on it. One would hope that the Indian government, and that of Maharashtra state, will take the same attitude, but I wouldn't count on it.

I would agree that the process for obtaining a tourist visa for India is unnecessarily complex. However, I would also say that is no more complex than the process of Indians trying to obtain a visa to USA (two appointments, fingerprinting + in person interview) or Europe. In either case, Indians have to prove that they are not going to "immigrate" to these countries by going there on a tourist visa. This places a much higher burden on Indians who just want to visit the Western world on holiday or business. Ideally, it would be a world where there are no visas, or if they must be present, they are fair and easy for all.

Agree 100 percent. Stupid bureaucratic rules that seem designed to deter, rather than encourage visitors. No Westerner is going to travel to India to work illegally or claim benefits -- as the visa rules appear to imply. Many Indians on the other hand would and do travel to the West to do exactly that! Hence the difficulties Indians have in obtaining visas for most developed countries. But these tit for tat regulations are counterproductive, losing India billons of dollars in lost  tourism earnings -- time to introduce visa on arrival as many countries do, that would also save atthe cost of maintaining overstaffed consulates everywhere. My British husband dreads our annual holiday in India (only because of the visa procedures, he loves it when he gets there)

I would also add that it isn't only the airports that needed upgrading, but the unbelievably complex, protracted and expensive process of obtaining a tourist visa for India needs to be addressed urgently. A month ago I applied for a new tourist visa – I've been visiting India for two decades – and found, as I do every time I apply, that there are new requirements, this time the submission of a certificate from my bank that I am financially solvent, a copy of the summary page of my most recent tax return, a list of every country I ave visited in the last 10 years blah blah blah. Then there is a 3-week wait while the government-appointed visa service issues a 6-month visa. It's reached the point of absurdity, and there must be tens of thousands of potential tourist who are deterred from visiting India by this process.

The Government of India has announced that there will be a "visa on arrival" process for citizens of more than 40 countries, but no date was specified, and with elections looming, we shouldn't hold our breath in anticipation of its implementation.

What will it take?  At minimum, a total ban on political campaign donations and supporting campaigns 100% from taxes and a requirement that all media must give equal space/time to each registered party without charging a dime.  The chance of these changes happening anytime soon?  Zero.
A critical mass of voting, voluntarism, or activism? I'm dying to see every American citizen as passionate, informed or engaged as some of us here... What else will it take!?
I thought that verse referred to people who sit around the church waiting for the rapture to take them away to heaven, not the poor who cannot find anyone to employ them.

There is some social Darwinism at work here. The Bible quote that those who do not work, nor shall they eat is doubly cruel not the least that many work and cannot feed their families. The Republicans do have a secret program to totally eliminate poverty. Poverty is eliminated by eliminating poor people. When 10 million die of starvation, exposure, untreated illness or injury you eliminate millions of potential Democratic voters and the drain on the treasury anti poverty programs require; thus creating the opportunity for tax cuts for the rich and the elimination of taxes on corporations.

To the GOP if a program or government expenditure helps poor people, we can’t afford it, if must be paid for while tax cuts for the rich never need be paid for and it created a moral hazard, laziness and dependency on the government. If poor people are not satisfied with the lot, they should borrow from their parents and open their own business and employ others, a Mitt Romney suggested. The worst thing for the economy is to increase the minimum wage while corporate officers make for in 15 minutes than the average worker makes in a year. People who never missed a meal cut food stamps and unemployment benefits leaving people who are seeking work in an economy which GOP policies destroyed with no means to feed themselves or pay the rent or continue a job search and if is for then own good. What will it take to get these hate filled, sadistic, hypocritical fascists our of public office?
Been there, done that..

This modern makeover does not address Europe and U.S bound travelers' greatest frustration with Mumbai's International Airport.

Anxiety begins as travelers attempt to enter the Terminal. Thorough passport and itinerary security checks begin outside the building, at curb side. There are very few (four, I recall) queues for the entire building. Waiting lines snake around for 100 yards and cross one another like roundabouts. You are expected to to select the proper queue but you cannot even see the entrance. All this commotion, in the dark, between 11PM and 2AM, the appropriate time to depart to make connections in Europe. Once inside the Terminal, the process moves smoothly even though the building may have been worn.

Looks great and sounds terrific. Hope it is designed to handle the monsoon rains which are decidedly heavier in Mumbai than they are in Delhi which in 2011 was completely flooded because of poor drainage planning.
Calling her simply by her (husband's) last name is what indicated widowhood.
Also known as 'local' Amazon.

Number of car parking spaces is extremely low. If just one each from Air India's Airbus and Boing's 9 models are at the terminal that will be 3790 passengers. Another 5 aircraft of Boing 787 at the terminal will surpass 5000 passengers. Even if we assume one passenger uses one car, the parking spaces are too few, and will result in overflow into traffic lanes. In most cases, Indians in several car loads send off and receive their family member. So definitely this will lead to traffic congestion.

It is great achievement of GVK ltd who has constructed world class Int Airport, Mumbai city shall become more bright.GVK ltd
has given befitting Airport to Mumbai city which is commercial hub of India

What is required is, there is wide spread displeasure about high taxes /charges being levied by state /central govt, Air port Authority of India & private Airport operators Air travel passengers complains so Air line companies.Hence state govt has to reduce taxes , so Airport Authority of India& Airport operators.

Mumbai Int Airport had many genuine problems ,foremost being space problem ,it is resolved now but due to unnecessary, avoidable delay cost of the project has overrun by to crores,for which Air travel passengers be not made to pay higher charges

WE, People of India give best wishes to GVK LtD ,Management of MIAL for giving world class Int Airport to Mumbai city.Passengers shall love it, so world Airline companies

One of the problems with intensively engaging Iran on anything, Professor, is that they and we are like two bears, warily circling one another: there still is no real trust here; and Mr. Obama's overtures via the about-to-be effective agreement that lightens sanctions in return for a promise to freeze nuclear development doesn't do much to help. Personally, I expect that even if Ian doesn't renege on its promises during the six months of this agreement, that the next phase, that requires serious commitment to de-nuclearization, will founder on their patent unwillingness to do this. So, where does that leave us (besides with an Iran now possessing a bomb)?

And they mistrust us because we lie athwart their clear desires to dominate the region.

So, a colloquy with Iran on Syria that involves Iran more directly engaged in peace efforts at our urging probably isn't in the cards.
I am glad you understand the monster that came to bite us on sept 11, 2001.
Richard, You may be right, but why this farce of diplomatic engagement with Iran then? For, if there's no trust backing such move, there's nothing to be gained by both the sides.

Before the already deteriorating situation in Syria goes out of control by turning Syria into yet another safe haven for the al-Qaida linked extremist Islamic terror groups, and thus a major threat to global stability and peace, the US and Iran should fully leverage upon their newly evolved relationship to find solution to the messy civil war in Syria. This could be possible if US in due recognition to the Itranian clout on Syria does honestly involve Iran with international diplomatic effort at ensuring the post-Assad political transition in Syria. As arming rebels seems no longer a viable option, rather sure to prove counterproductive. If Iran somehow succeeds at persuading Assad to quit, even the Saudi Arabia could scale back its current support to the militant Sunni Islamic groups. The US should seize on the opportunity by pushing for the Iran involving global diplomatic initiative  without ever thinking of any Afghanistan like folly of arming rebels, and thereby creating the Frankstein's monster of global terrorism.
I agree, though definitely wouldn't call the local food culture in India healthy.

Domino’s Pizza, KFC, Baskin & Robbins, Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf, Mad Over Donuts and Pizza Hut - really?  In the NEW airport?  This type of low grade, unhealthy food seems more 1970's that 2014.  I travel a lot and the quality of food available in airports plays a big role in my experience.  I am sure I am not alone in this.  This is especially sad in India, which has such a wonderful, healthy local food culture.  Sad, really, really sad.
Looks nice.  Looking forward to using it on a trip to India in 2015.
This is a wonderful story. Although having people tell him the stories is certainly more human, could someone donate him books on tape?

Andy, why do you call this hoarding. Which is a problem when people fill living space with compulsively gathered objects.
Why not "collecting"? Collecting is one of the fascinating traits of humans.
In the case of Mr. Latif, he's bartering books for stories and enriching his life with ideas and experiences available to him in his oral tradition since he's illiterate.

For informed and up-to-date midwifery practice incorporating traditional midwifery practice with modern (life saving) medical safety procedures, I encourage all to research the work of the International Midwife Association (IMA) an organization founded to train midwives in war torn rural Afghanistan and now works primarily in Nigeria, training midwives in best birthing practices. Excellent work and a hybrid methodology that has much to offer India.
Not to mention fantasy... Nothing ever works out the way politicians say they're going to, especially these days.

Anyone who believes that GOP office-holders and would-be presidents are suddenly concerned about the poor is either naive or foolish. Paul Ryan, the last Republican VP nominee (you remember his campaign outreach to the poor in 2012, putting on an apron and pretending to wash a pot at a food pantry), has repeatedly expressed his concern that "the safety net is becoming a hammock". His mean-spirited House budget plan called for a $40 billion slash in food stamps. Marco Rubio recently gave a speech about poverty but offered no help, other than the GOP's favorite solution--block grants to the states (who will then feel free to restrict eligibility and slash benefits). He sees no reason to raise the minimum wage to $10/hour because people should want to focus on making $50/hour.

Today's Republicans are governed by one over-riding principle: those who have the most should get more and those who have the least should get less. Their contempt for poor people (takers, the 47%, etc.) is seldom hidden. Their taxaphobic philosophy means that deficit reduction can only be reduced by cutting spending--except of course, for their rich friends (e.g. the House Farm Bill).

They claim that unemployment benefits can only be extended if they are paid for; the benefits were supposed to be "temporary".

The same could be said of the Bush tax cuts--a "temporary" measure passed to give back the budget surpluses to the people. But to repeal that is GOP heresy.

Charming...and poignant.  He has transformed pieces of  printed and bound paper into human exchanges, artful delights, and treasures for his children to inherit. Do you not understand the value of books? Thank you for this beautiful portrait, Mr Maqbool! Hoarding? I think not!

Sure, or you could look to Germany, Poland, the Netherlands, and Sweden to see how nationalization works splendidly in governmental systems that, in action, resemble our own much more closely.  Especially with Germany and the Netherlands which does what this article actually suggests: only nationalize when a bank is a threat/in trouble, such as many were after the 2008 crisis.  Bail them out, but as a consequence nationalize.  This has worked brilliantly in non-tyrannical, non-banana republic economies.

"Lords of Finance: The Bankers That Broke the World"  Don't have to read it.  I'm living it, along with millions of others who will never recover from the Great Recession of 2008 caused by our too big to fail banks.

A nationalized bank would not be in the business of competing with international banks or gambling with depositors money. It would be in the business of providing its customers, the citizens and businesses of the  United States, with a fair banking system the exists for the benefit of those citizens and business. The big banks have become unregulated, corrupt gambling casinos that have no interest in their customers, except to squeeze every penny they can out of them. As for expertise, they are only experts at rigged gambling because they have created and exist in a rigged system. Professional Las Vegas gamblers are more experienced, they have to compete without the benefits that the big banks have of a closed system. Cuba, the former Soviet Union and Venezuela are obviously false analogies  and known as such to anyone who is familiar with  banking and world history.

Oh my, nationalize banks, and just who would run these banks now owned by the citizens? Would the managers be political appointees, or Civil Service managers? Where would the expertise come from to compete with the international banks, or would you make laws preventing people from using those other banks, and what happens when one of these nationalized banks loses money, who gets the ax, by whom, more politicians.

We have had over a century of nationalization by various countries to see how that works, just read "Lords of Finance: The Bankers That Broke The World" to see the results.
What do you think the Soviet system was, of the Cuban system is, and today you can follow Venezuela to see how well it is doing.

I for one would not do business with a nationalized bank, I can not afford to lose what I have left now.
